OK, so let's do a quick
review of last lecture. So last time, we started
talking about gyroscopes.

And we started by
basically developing a mathematical
framework that enables

us to study rotations, the
physics of rotating bodies, basically. Specifically, we talked about
different reference frames

or coordinate systems. So if you have a fixed frame,
S0, and a rotating reference frame S-sub-r with some
angular velocity vector omega,

then we showed
that a given point that is moving in
both reference frames.

Some point p of t, we showed
how the time derivatives of the position are related
in the two reference frames.

So the time derivative
p-dot in the fixed frame is equal to the time
derivative in the rotating

frame plus this extra
term omega cross p. So the vector cross product
of your angular velocity

vector and the position. And in terms of
physical quantities,

these are velocities. So the velocity you
observe in the fixed frame is going to be, of
course, different

from the velocity
you observe if you're tied to the rotating frame. And this mathematical
expression exactly

shows you the relationship
between the two. Now, from there,
we started looking

at the forces that are observed
in the two reference frames. Why forces?

Because inertial sensors,
as we know, measure forces.

So that was done by basically
starting from Newton's law,

F equals m times a, and then
taking the second derivative of the position.

So basically, taking another
derivative of this equation, and then we were able
to relate the forces.

And this is the expression
we came up with, that the force in the rotating
reference frame, F in sr,

is equal to the
force in the fixed frame plus 3 additional terms.

The first one is called
the Coriolis force, and it's given by this
expression, minus 2m omega

cross p-dot. So it's proportional
to the angular velocity of the rotating frame and
the velocity of the particle

in the rotating frame p-dot. Then there is the
centrifugal force which is given by this
expression, minus m omega cross

omega cross p, so it is
proportional in a way

to the position of the particle
and the square of the angular

velocity. And finally, you
have your Euler force which is given by
this expression, minus m omega dot cross p.

So it's proportional to the
position of the particle and its angular acceleration.

So this is omega dot here. And specifically, we said
the type of accelerometer

that we are going to study in
detail, which is a laboratory mechanical accelerometer,
essentially

measures the Coriolis force
or the Coriolis acceleration. So this F divided by m,
that would be your Coriolis

acceleration. And that-- or the magnitude of
that acceleration, Coriolis,

is going to be directly
proportional to the angular velocity.

And also proportional to, of
course, the linear velocity of the particle.

So if the linear
velocity is known and you can measure the
Coriolis acceleration,

you basically by
this simple equation you can find out what
the angular velocity was.

And this is the
principle of operation of the type of gyroscope that
we are going to study in detail.

So essentially, with all
the math that we developed and the physics that
we did on top of it,

and we basically
got to this point, this is something
very actionable

because it essentially
tells us that if we can build a very specific
type of accelerometer that

can measure Coriolis
acceleration, by doing the simple
math, you can essentially

make it a gyroscope. So the gyroscope or this
specific type of gyroscope

you're studying, down the hood,
it's really an accelerometer. But it's measuring
a very specific type

of acceleration, which is
the Coriolis acceleration. And then that can be easily
converted to angular velocity.

OK, and then we started
looking at essentially the mechanical architecture
of this type of accelerometer

given in this figure here. So inside the device, and
this is a one-dimensional one.

So it is going to measure
angular velocities that

are with respect
to the axis that is going in and out of the plane.

So this orange arrow here
shows you the direction

of the rotation or
the angular velocity that the device will measure. And internal to the device,
it's again a damped spring mass

system which shouldn't be a
surprise because we said down the hood this is really
an accelerometer.

But it's going to measure a very
specific type of acceleration. And the way that is
achieved, basically,

it has two axes
of motion that are

perpendicular to each other. One is called the drive
axis or the drive direction,

also called the primary
mode of the device. And in this axis called
that x sub r, we basically

actively drive this harmonic
oscillator with some drive

force, F sub d. So that force is
generated internally in the device with some
actuation mechanism

that we'll talk about. So if that-- so
that force is going to cause some movement
in the xr direction.

And then on top of that, if
you have some angular motion or angular velocity
in omega, what

happens is that the two
will generate a Coriolis acceleration in the
perpendicular direction, which

we call y sub r. And that's called the secondary
mode or the sense direction.

Let's make sure
this makes sense. So if go here to the
projector, again, you're

going to have your
primary mode generating velocity in this
direction in xr,

and then you have
your angular velocity that we want to sense defined by
omega coming out of the plane.

So as we know, the Coriolis
acceleration is given, or the vector is given by omega
cross, the linear velocity.

So linear velocity
is in x direction. Omega is out of the plane. You do your right hand rule.

So the Coriolis
acceleration is going to be in the y sub r direction.

So then I think everything
should make sense. So now we have this
accelerometer in the sense

direction, and the acceleration
that it would sense is going to be the

So essentially, you're

You plug-in your charge

squared over C, OK? So that's the total energy in

That's the amount

So you have Fdx, that's

equal the amount of electromagnetic

So you convert some of the

mass, large n and large h.

Something very interesting

that you're generating in xr. But if it goes up down,

sensitive to y movement,

to x movement when it comes to picking things up.

And then dampening, exactly

these MEMs devices

There's two reasons for it. One is more signal. You always want to get as
much signal as you can.

So if there is some
surface or area available to add more capacitive
sensors, you would do that.

But also because of the thing
we were talking about here,

the mass is going to move
to the left and right. Then you get a net nonzero
change of capacitance

on one side, which means
you would couple your drive movement to what you want to
sense, which is the Coriolis

acceleration. So it just-- the device
wouldn't even function. You cannot decoupled-- from the
perspective of your capacitive

sensor, it's going to be
sensitive to both movement in x and in y direction,
and that's not desired.

You want your capacitor to
only respond to movement in the drive axis, which is
due to Coriolis acceleration.

When you put it on both sides,
when it goes left and right, one side is going
to lose capacitance,

the other side is going
to gain capacitance. So there's a net zero change
in capacitance on both sides,

and that means you're
insensitive to horizontal motion. You're only sensitive
to up down motion,

which is the motion
you want to sense, OK? So that's also a
very-- so it's not just to get more signal, that's nice.

But also, practically, if
you remove one of these, your device wouldn't
function because it's

going to respond to both your
drive movement and the Coriolis movement, which is not desired.

OK. So the answer is like--
there's two very clever things in the design that helps the
device basically differentiate

or only be sensitive
to angular motion and not linear acceleration.

So the first thing is that
you cannot fully decouple. So there is going to be
a little bit of coupling

from external linear
acceleration to the device. And it's going to look like
a little bit of added noise

if there's external
acceleration applied. But most of it, you can fully
filter out by two things.

One is remember, this
F sub d we generated,

and it's going to be driven
at a very specific frequency. You pick your
omega d, and that's

the resonance frequency
of the device, and your response in
the sense direction

is also going to be
exactly at that frequency. So just by some
filtering operation,

if you only look at the
response at omega d--

if you do a sharp
bandpass filter and only look at that
resonant frequency,

that's going to
already filter out a lot of external
acceleration that you can apply because it's
probably going to be wideband

or completely out of band. So that's one. You only look at the frequency
that you're driving it at,

and that's going to and
filter everything else out. Now, having said that, it
means that if somebody somehow

knows what the drive frequency
of your gyroscope is, they can disruptively attack it.

So they can generate,
for instance, acoustic waves at
that exact frequency and couple it to
your device if they

know the resonant frequency,
and then they can really, really, really disrupt the
performance of your device

if they actually externally
couple accelerations at that frequency.

The second thing that helps you
is if I go to this last picture

we looked at-- and
this one is very dependent on the
architecture of the device. But for this one
specifically, for instance,

what kind of

And that's why these

As you apply angular velocity,

one of them is going to

and the other one is

to go in opposite directions.

Again, it's going to be
either like this or like that. So the signals that

but they're going to
have the same sign. If it's coming from a

by design, lets you
decouple rotation from linear acceleration.
Make sense? OK. So there's two things. There's filtering. Just look at omega d.

come up with analytical

or the standard
deviation of the noise that accelerometers experience,

due to thermal effects. So thermal effects cause these
random vibrations of the proof mass, and they are going to
show up as some random angular

velocities in the device. The expression for the RMS
value or the standard deviation

of the noise is given by this. So high level takeaway
for us is typically,

angular velocities that are
less than the standard deviation of noise, they're not

They're just like
below noise rule. In some more sensitive
applications, you might require things to be

to declare them detectable. And then if you look at the
noise variance or standard

deviation, it's proportional
to a number of things. Of course, the measurement
bandwidth, delta F is there,

you have the temperature, you
have the Boltzmann constant, but the damping
factor is in there.

So smaller damping
factors also help with reducing the noise in the
device, another reason to have

these devices underdamped. It's also inversely
proportional to mass,

displacement in the
primary direction, and the resonance
frequency of the device. So if those
parameters are large,

it will also help with reducing
the noise that device picks up. So again, these go
into design trade offs

because linear accelerations,
at least a little bit of it, will couple into the

frequency of about 1 kilohertz.

model is. So essentially, you have
your true underlying angular velocities, omega,
and there is going

to be some noise
added to it, omega n, and these are, in the most
general case, vectors in R3

if you have a three axis device. So you have omega plus omega n. That's being
multiplied by this 3

by 3 matrix, which models
two effects for you, a crosstalk and a sensitivity
variations in different axes.

So your diagonal entries of
your m, which we call alphas, those are sensitivity errors.

Ideally, you want
them to be all one. But in practice, there's
going to be some deviation. And then the off
diagonal, the kappas

are your crosstalk
basically term. So that's when angular
velocity from one axis

couples and shows up as angular
velocity in the different axis. And then you also always have
a bias term beta, which is just

a constant vector added. These devices are
typically well calibrated.

So your M is almost
identical to--

almost the identity. If it's a well calibrated
device, that's what you get.

So there's almost no crosstalk
and almost no gainers.

I mean, in practice, it's
never exactly identity. There's always a little bit
of residual miscalibration.

Noise is noise, nothing
we can do about that, and there is also always a
little bit of residual bias.

And device datasheets actually
give you these parameters. So they tell you, for
instance, how much

crosstalk you should

expect from your device.

So these are parameters

So we're going to

Again, dead reckoning-- you
can use different sensors to do that. We're going to look at
the inertial version of it

basically. OK. So this is called
inertial navigation, and it's, as I said, dead
reckoning using measurements

from accelerometers and gyros. And there's a term for it. It's called Inertial
Navigation System or INS.

So what an INS is
is basically, it's your IMU, which is an
accelerometer and a gyroscope,

plus a little bit of an extra
compute in the form of a DSP

processor and a
microcontroller that processes the signals
from the gyroscope

and the accelerometers,
and essentially does a little bit of
dead reckoning for you

and gives you trajectories
or positions and velocities. So it integrates the outputs
of these two sensors.

So that combined thing is called
INS or Inertial Navigation

Systems. So when it comes
to buying devices, you can buy just accelerometers
or gyroscopes or the combined

one, which is axial gyro
or axial gyro magnetometer. You can also buy
INS's which does

the processing of the
signals also for you, and it does that little
bit of perception for you.

But we want to
learn how to do that from scratch because
there's a lot of very

important details in how
it should be done properly. So for dead reckoning,
again, the problem statement

is, you have some robot,
some vehicles, something that is moving with respect
to a global reference frame

which is fixed. So we call that S sub g. So that's our fixed
world reference frame

or the global reference frame. Again, it can point to fixed
geographical directions like North, East, down,
or something like that.

And then you have an
INS on your robot, which is accelerometer,
gyroscope plus a little bit

of additional signal processing. The signals that you get
out of your accelerometer

and gyroscope, the device
has no idea about your world coordinates.

So it's going to report
these quantities, which are acceleration ins
and angular velocities,

in its own reference frame. So if this blue box is your IMU,
it's going to have its own x,

y, z coordinates. We call it S sub b for--
that's the body reference frame of the device,
and the values

the device is going to
report is with respect to its own reference frame.

So in order to be able to do
that reckoning-- of course, it's only useful in our
global reference frame,

so we need to
transform the readouts of the device from its
body reference frame

to the global reference frame
before we integrate those. So very concretely,
let's say you have an accelerometer on some
vehicle, and it's telling you,

you're going in x direction
with an acceleration of 1 meters per second squared.

But what is x
direction with respect to geographical coordinates? Is it pointing to the North?

Is it South? Is it East? Is it West? Is it something in between? You need to know that,
and then transform

that read out from
the body coordinates to the global coordinates
before you integrate and do

that reckoning. That's a critical step
that needs to be done, OK? So because of that, there
is two different types

of inertial navigation systems. One is called a
stable platform INS.

So a stable platform
INS, what it does is that it has what
we call gimbals, which

are these-- it has a moving
platform inside the device with motors in it in three axes.

And it uses the readouts
from the gyroscope. And as soon as it senses there
is some rotation being applied,

it correct for it. So it always aligns
your accelerometers with the global--

basically, external
global reference frame. And it's doing that by
physically moving the device.

So as you can imagine,
the stable platform INS has become these
big clunky things

with multiple motors and
gimbals and things like that. And they're big,
they're expensive,

they have a lot of
limitations, but they also can be very, very accurate.

So for instance in spacecrafts
and very expensive airplanes, these type of accelerometers
are used as stable platform.

And by that basically
correcting for the orientation of the device and
always aligning it

with an external
reference frame, you always-- basically
you eliminate the problem of having two
different reference frames

because you always
actively align your sensor to the external reference. So your S sub b, which is your
body reference coordinates,

is always equal to the
global reference coordinates. So that's a stable platform.

And let's see a quick
movie of one of these because these are
fascinating things.

Then we have a strapdown
INS, which basically has none

of these active control stuff. So it's exactly just
one chip with gyroscopes

and accelerometers
inside, and it has no way of correcting this basically--

the discrepancy between
the body reference frame with the global

mechanically, so it has to
be done in signal processing. And the strapdown
ins is the one we

will study in detail

that most likely you
would be dealing with. OK. So when it comes to doing
dead reckoning or inertial

navigation with these two
different types of systems, let's look at the INS-- the
stable platform INS first.

So with the stable platform
INS, you basically--

again, your
accelerometer is always aligned with your global
reference coordinates.

So it's very easy. You just take the accelerometer
readouts, you subtract the gravity component--

you should always subtract
the gravity component because the gravity component
that the device senses

is actually through contact. So again, if it's like
sitting on this table, it's going to sense
a 1g pointing up,

and that's just
a balancing force applied through the
contact to balance out

the pull of gravity. So you always want
to subtract that out because that doesn't
cause any motion.

So subtract the
gravity, then you get accelerations in the
global reference frame.

You integrate once,
you get velocity. You integrate again,
you get global position. Very easy.

So that's the stable platform. It's not what we're
going to study. That's too easy for us. So we're going to
look at strapdown.

With strapdown, what
you do, you need to do a little bit of sensor
fusion between your gyroscope

and accelerometers. So from the gyroscope readouts,
which are angular velocities,

if you integrate
those-- and we'll see how to integrate
them, you can get essentially the
orientation relative

to the global reference frames. And you use that
orientation information

to transform your accelerometer
readouts from the body frame to the global frame.

So you apply this 3D
rotation basically to your accelerometer
readouts, then you can subtract
gravity components,

and then you get acceleration
in the global reference frame. You can integrate
once to get velocity,

integrate again to get position. So essentially, what this step
does for you, transforming--

which uses the gyroscope input
or the integrated gyroscope input to apply that
transformation,

that is the
algorithmic equivalent of what a stable INS does
for you mechanically.

So the stable INS
just mechanically moves the thing to align it.

In the strapdown, you apply
a rotation in math or in DSP or in algorithms to
do the alignment.

So the end effect is the same. You want to get accelerations
in the global frame,

and then integrate
those basically to get that reckoning.

OK. I'm not going to spend
too much time on this. I think we talked about pros
